segments.text: Oh.
Well, just the thought of going back to where he lost so many good people.
And in one of his letters to me, in talking about it, he really admired the bravery of all the rangers that served under him.
He said they gave their all as good soldiers should.
And it is.
So in 54, when the writer, Bill Hines, called and asked Earl if he would go back to France, take him, our son, and he wanted to do an article for the 10th anniversary of D-Day.
Merrill wasn't sure at all that he could go back to where he lost all those people.
But we kept working on seeing what it would mean to our son to be able to go there.
So he did.
And then I said he was, that was in 54.
And then 55, that's after he took office at the land office at General Eisenhower, President Eisenhower.
asked him to be his representative to the 10th anniversary of the liberation of Colmar, which his regiment liberated.
And he went back for that.
And then in 1964, he was asked to go back for the 20th anniversary of D-Day.
And that was nice.
And then in 69, British TV did a film called
Ten men went to war.
And Earl was the only one from the United States that was asked to go for that.
And he took our younger son with him then.
And he never got to see the movie.
You see, they went in fall of 69.
I'm not sure his father's been.
But anyway, it was shown in England for the 25th anniversary of D-Day.
And at the time they made this film, they were negotiating with CBS to show it over here.
But that never did work out.
So we finally, after his death, see, like I say, he never saw it.
We did get a copy of the film.
And what they did for each of these 10 men, they filmed them where something significant happened to them.
in France.
And then they filmed them in what their present day job was.
So they sent four fellas over here from the British TV company.
And so they arranged a core review and a lot of things for them here.
That'll probably be a good show for A&M, you know.
But that was 69, and as I say, he got sick in January of 75.
Well, you were First Lady, and what exactly was your role?
Well, there was lots of entertaining, which I'm sure has happened to all of them through the years.
One thing that we...
had that we enjoyed, and I still run into some of those fellows now, but we had student leader meetings every month in the house.
And I never did get to sit in on the meetings.
I said, I was so good, I got to serve refreshments, then I could disappear.
So, I always wanted to know what they had to talk about, but I never did that.
Then we entertained a lot.
Contrary to some things that have been said, we did
Actually, we were the first ones to live in the new President's House, which was not so new anymore.
We moved into that in October of 1965, having been the last ones to live in the old President's House, which burned in 63.
And then in October of 65, we moved into the one I still call the new one.
They had an interesting history on how they made it.
Do you want to tell us some of the things about making it?
Well, it really did kind of connect the generations, I guess, in a way.
The home that is there now, the Pagan's Home, built from brick that was handmade in Hearn in the early 1890s.
They built the science hall from it.
And at the time the old President's House burned, they had already planned to tear the science hall down and build a new building there.
So they reserved enough of that brick to build the President's House.
I had one old professor who's no longer living came up to me one day in the grocery store.
He said, you know, it just does my heart good to look over there at that house.
I spent 40 years of my life behind that brick.
Anyway, there were so many nice donations that were made to the building of the house that my husband always called it the best bargain the state of Texas had.
Bob Bernath, who was a concrete man here in town,
He gave all the concrete for all these driveways and things around it.
Fort Allbritton, who was on the board, gave the doors and windows.
And Dow Chemical, Dr. Boyle was on the board.
They gave the insulation.
And there were other donations to it.
So I remember my husband saying that it cost $60,000.
And at the time it was built, it had 6,500 square feet.
So that was a bargain by anybody's estimation.
Of course, now it's unbelievable.
It was a very livable home.
And we entertained a lot.
And we had things like a statewide garden club meeting, had East Texas Chamber of Commerce.
Didn't you put some dogwoods in the house one time?
Didn't you put some dogwood blossoms in the house one time?
That was for East Texas Chamber of Commerce.
I had visited my college roommate who lives at Williamsburg and was riding the dogwood.
It was in full bloom and I just loved it.
So I came back with a carload of it, in water of course.
And we decorated the entire downstairs of the house with all the wood.
It was really pretty.
I think it was my favorite decoration of all the times.
But see, I love to do flowers.
And I would do the flowers for all the entertainment we did.
I ordered them one time.
We first moved into the house before anything grew back of the house.
and my husband let me pay for it out of their household budget, which I didn't have much in that budget anyway.
So I decided I'd better learn to arrange flowers.
I loved that.
How's your role different from Mrs. Mulberry's role?
I don't really know.
I'm sure they did a lot of entertaining, too, like we did, where she's teaching this year.
And so I guess they can't do as much.
But I guess it's pretty standard that anybody that has that position can expect to do a lot of entertaining.
And it was always fun.
We used to have faculty groups, student groups, you name it.
But through that life, you get to meet so many interesting people.
Some of the people you've met were Lyndon Johnson and Omar Badri.
Oh, everybody from A to Z. I'd have to stop and think a while.
We've met from kings on down.
You just never know who's going to.
That's the nice thing about a university environment.
You do get to meet so many people.
And of course, we love the football.
This is an interview with Margaret Rutter by Lisa Rush on May 5th, 1993 at Mrs. Rutter's house concerning her life at A&M during the 60s and World War II.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that alright with you?
Okay.
Thank you.
